metadata.title: Hydrotherapy  Halliwick Concept
description: The Halliwick Concept was first conceived as a strategy to teach swimming to individuals with disabilities.(1,2,14) The concept was devised by a swimming coach and focuses on structuring activities in the water in a progressive way. Emphasis is placed on breath control and control of rotations in the aquatic environment(1,2,16)
When Halliwick was first developed it was called the Halliwick Method. The name has been changed to Halliwick Concept to suggest a broader framework in which Halliwick can be applied(3,14)
The Halliwick Concept is now used for therapeutic activities as well as for traditional swimming instruction(3,16)

The Halliwick Concept emphasizes the benefits of activities in water, including physical, recreational, and social interaction –The participants’ enjoyment of the activity is believed to enhance the learning
The goal is to enable the participant to achieve maximum independence both in the water and on land

Manual assistance from an able-bodied  instructor, requiring a one-on-one  approach, is used. Withdrawal of assistance (disengagement) occurs as the participant progresses. Flotation aids are never used(16)

Many activities take place in groups –Although one-on-one  pairing is the standard, pairs work in groups to provide socialization, peer interaction, and opportunity for development of skills in game activities(4)
indications: The Halliwick Concept is used to allow individuals with or without a disability to participate in water activities
Commonly used as aquatic therapy in neurological and pediatric rehabilitation(16)
reimbursement: The clinician is advised to check with the patient’s specific insurance carrier to obtain reimbursement information

Funding for therapy often targets essential functional needs and does not extend to sports such as swimming. In many cases working in the pool needs to be justified by functional improvement that will take place on land(2) Indications for the Halliwick Concept

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What is the nature of the referral?

course of treatment.medical management: What medical procedures, surgeries, and/or inpatient hospital stays has the patient had? Medical management will vary widely depending on underlying condition/reason for referral
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective in controlling the patient’s symptoms?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests will vary depending on the nature of the condition
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Document any prior hydrotherapy as well as any prior swimming experience

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Choose an instrument to measure pain that  gives consideration to patient’s developmental level. The FLACC scale or Oucher scale can be used for young children or patients who are nonverbal
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any history of respiratory compromise? History of supplemental oxygen use or the need for a mechanical ventilator? Any history of asthma? Chlorine by-products  in the air at pools (indoor in particular) can be irritants that can aggravate asthma and other respiratory conditions(10) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe -Limitations in postural control, head control, and control of voluntary movement can increase the feeling of threat during immersion.(11) Mental adjustment is often a prolonged process for individuals with these impairments

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Ask about conditions that are contraindications for hydrotherapy, such as incontinence and recent uncontrolled seizure activity
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities? Does the patient attend school or work? Inquire about patient’s experiences with swimming and comfort level in water
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient or caregiver report any limitations in self-care,  home management, school/work activity, or community/leisure participation? Does the patient use any adaptive equipment? Note what assistance and adaptive equipment maybe needed during therapy, including to assist entry and exit to pool and to change into and out of swimsuit
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Identify what community resources are available and whether patient can access them

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Assess edema as indicated (e.g., circumferential measurements). Measure for leg-length discrepancy where indicated
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document assistive and adaptive devices and patient’s level of independence in their use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Complete a balance assessment in sitting and standing. Examples of standardized tests include the Berg Balance Scale and the Functional Reach Test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess respiratory rate and pattern at rest and throughout hydrotherapy session
Assess BP and heart rate before and after activity as indicated
Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used to assess perceived intensity of exercise
6-minute  walk test (6MWT) can be used to assess endurance
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Assess radial and pedal pulses –Note capillary refill time in fingers and toesAssess general body mechanics throughout sessionComplete a full assessment of mobility; use standardized tests such as Timed Up and Go (TUG) test or functional independence measure (FIM) as indicated. Assess transfer ability with consideration to how patient will enter and exit pool. Depending on facility, patient may be required to walk in or to maintain balance in unsupported sitting while being lowered in
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Depending on reason for referral, a gait assessment may be indicated. Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used to assess safety during gaitAssess the integrity of any involved joints. Assess for contractures where indicatedComplete an assessment of motor function as indicated by reason for referral –Assess voluntary motor control and presence of any obligatory movement patterns –Assess muscle tone – Modified Ashworth Scale can be used –Assess coordination as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Warm or hot water temperature and full-body  immersion have a tendency to cause transient weakness during or immediately following hydrotherapy sessions(9) –Assess core muscle strength –Complete a full strength assessment as indicated and appropriate –May need to assess strength through function in some situations -Manual muscle testing (MMT) is not valid where tone or coordination is abnormalAssess as indicated using a standardized scale such as –Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2);  ages 4–21  years –Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory (PEDI); ages 6 months to 7 years; ADL component –Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2); birth to age 5 years
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture, noting any asymmetry in weight-bearing  in sitting and standing. Assess anteroposterior spinal curves, noting any excess lordosis or kyphosis. Assess for scoliosis where indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Complete a full active and passive ROM and flexibility assessment as indicated and appropriate
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess reflexes bilaterally and compareAssess ADLs as indicated. Barthel Index can be used. Note amount of assistance required for dressing. Changing for hydrotherapy may be personnel-  and time-intensive
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –A variety of tools for evaluating adjustment and functional ability in the aquatic environment have been developed, including the Aquatic Adjustment Test, Water Orientation Checklist, Water Orientation Test of ALYN 1 and 2 (WOTA 1 and WOTA 2), and Swimming with Independence Measure (SWIM) –Most have not addressed reliability and validity issues –WOTA 1 and WOTA 2 were developed based on the principles of the Halliwick Concept(11) -WOTA 1 is for children with special needs who have difficulty following simple verbal commands; WOTA 2 is for children with special needs who can readily follow instructions -The tests are clinically relevant for assessing function of patients with both motor and cognitive deficits -Both tests have been demonstrated to be reliable and valid –SWIM is a Halliwick Concept–based  measure that was introduced to assess the swimming skills and progression of an individual swimmer(12) -Authors of a study conducted in Slovenia found that content validity is high up to the point at which a swimmer is well adapted to water and already able to learn some swimming techniques. Interrater reliability is very high(12) -Further studies on its sensitivity and internal validity are recommended
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess orientation as indicated. The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) can be used to screen for cognitive impairment. Obtain cognitive/psychological testing results from other professions where available (16)

other: Patients with a diagnosis for which the Halliwick Concept of hydrotherapy is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies ›Diagnosis/need for the Halliwick Concept of hydrotherapy:  Persons with or without disabilities who can benefit from a structured program of activities in water to learn to swim or to improve independent movement in water and on land

treatment summary: The Halliwick Concept of hydrotherapy might improve balance and gait in patients who have had a stroke(13) –Based on a German RCT involving 30 patients who had had a stroke –Patients were randomly assigned to a Halliwick group or to a conventional physical therapy group –Patients in the Halliwick group received 45 minutes of aquatic therapy 3 times per week and conventional physical therapy twice a week –Patients in the conventional physical therapy group received treatment five times per week –Patients in the Halliwick group had greater improvement in gait as measured by the functional ambulation categories –There were no statistically significant differences in the Berg Balance Scale or Rivermead Mobility Index

A case report from Italy on the use of the Halliwick Concept as exclusive therapy for a patient with spastic paralysis post stroke suggests that the Halliwick Concept might be useful in the earliest phase of neurorehabilitation after stroke(5) –Starting 15 days after stroke, the patient participated in Halliwick Concept hydrotherapy alone for 4 weeks, followed by 4 weeks of Halliwick Concept hydrotherapy in combination with Bobath method treatment –Outcome measures included the U.S. National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), Modified Ashworth Scale, Motricity Index, Trunk Control Test, Sitting Balance Score, Functional Ambulation Classification, and Barthel Index –There was an improvement in the participant’s scores on all scales

Results of a pilot study conducted in Spain suggest that a combined program of dry land physical therapy and Halliwick Concept hydrotherapy may improve ROM in adults with hypertonia due to brain injury(6) –Seven patients participated in 24 sessions consisting of 12 hydrotherapy sessions and 12 physical exercise sessions on dry land –A pre- and posttest design was used –Outcome measures included maximum passive joint ROM, resistance to passive movement of the ankle (Modified Ashworth Scale), and electromyographic recording during the stretching of the soleus muscle –Passive ankle joint ROM increased. No statistically significant differences were found in the Modified Ashworth Scale or the electrical activity of the soleus muscle

In a case study conducted in Mexico, a hydrotherapy program using the Halliwick Method improved muscular endurance and flexibility in a patient with poliomyelitis sequelae (post-polio  syndrome)(15) –A 35-year-old  female with poliomyelitis sequelae that included leg immobility and spasticity, scoliosis, and wheelchair use completed Halliwick activities for 90 minutes 5 times a week for 4 months –Muscular endurance was evaluated by counting arm curls completed in 30 seconds holding a hand weight. Shoulder flexibility was measured using the “back scratch test” –The main findings were that 16 weeks of hydrotherapy using the Halliwick method improved endurance and flexibility in this patient .
